div.head: The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £ 19.4.11.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for SUDAN, SUAKIN, direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidan, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yamboas required. and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Cotton Worm.
Cotton worm has appeared on several estates near Zsgazig.
New Markaz.
The Government has decided to create a new markaz at Kbargeb, Assiont province.
Drowned.
A boy and girl were drowned while washing themselves in the Nubarieh Canal at Tod on Monday.
The Brindisi Mall.
The mail from Earope, via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at tbe G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 4 45 p.m. to day.
Asile Rudolph.
Mr. H.B. Carver, Mansoorab, and M.Gentili «.have sent a quantity of old clothes for the poor folks dependent on the 4 site Rudolph. Alexandria.
All Saints', Cairo.
Tomorrow (Aecension Day) there will be a celebration of Holy Communion at 8 a.m. and morning prayer at 9.30 a.m. at All Saints . Church, Cairo.
Children's Dance.
A children’s danoe, organised by Prof. Longbi, will take place at the Z'zioia Theatre on Saturday next, commeuciog at -1 p.m. The professor’s -pupils will take part.
The Decoration Craze.
An enquiry has been opened into theconduct of three Cairene notables who are accused of extorting seven hundred pounds from an omdeb on the promise of procuring a decoration for him.
A. Sayldeh Mouled.
The Moulei of Sayidoh Patimeb el Naha- wieb was held at Darb el-Ahmar, Cairo, two days ago under the presidency of the Governor of Cairo, who distributed gifts among the poor the same evening.
Hashish Smuggling.

The Cairo Cutom hoose authorities have confiscated a number of barre'a which contained 8C0 okes of hashish consigned to an Italian contractor in the Capital. The barrels were supposed to contain cement
France-ltallan Festival

Owing to some misunderstanding, the band of the Royal Doblin Fusiliers did not play at the Franco Italian festival in the ‘‘French Garden” last night. We understand, however, that arrangements have been made for its performing this evening.
A.L.M. A D.8.

The lecture to be given under the auspices of tne Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic 8ociety by Mr. R: Williams, F.R.I.B.A., on “Architecture and Progress,” bas been unavoidably postponed to Monday, the 28th inst., at 9 p.m. The lecture will take place at the Sailors and Soldiers’ Institute.
Husband Hacked to Pisces.

Our Damanhonr Correspondent states that the Damanhonr Parquet was foil of people on Monday to witness the trial of a woman from Reman Demisa (north of Damanhonr) who bad murdered her baBband and ont bis body into pieoee. Tbe band of the murdered mao was found in tbs bouse of the prisoner, who has confessed her crime.
Love and Arson.

Our Damanhonr Correspondent writes:— The chiefs of the tribes of Aboa Haida and Abou Sbilif both wanted the same girl as a wife for their respective sons. Being a kinswoman of Aboa Sbilif the latter claimed her for bis son by right. The girl’s father, however, favoured the soit of Aboa Haida’s son, and the result wss a fend between the two tribes. This morning (Taesday) tbe girl’s father found his hayçtack, valued at over a hundred pounds, burnt to the groand, and be suspects the son of Aboa Sbilif of having set fire to it.
English, Italian, French.

The knowledge of these three languages mentioned above — entitled official in Lord Cromer's report—becomes more necessary every day to all living in Egypt. It is acquired in a short time, and in an attractive manner, in tbe Berlitz 8obools of Cairo,''!', Sharia Kamel, and of Alexandria, 12, rue Rosette,as the numerous attestations of old popils prove. Trial lesson free. [Advt]

div.head: ENGLAND AND RUSSIA
div.p: Reapproachment making steady progress
YILDIZ DISPLAYS INTEREST
Gazatto's Special
London, Wednesday.

The Anglo Russian rapprochement appears to be making steady progrès*, notwithstanding the reports to the contrary. The general opinion here is 1b wt the "Standard’s” articles are based on reliable information. Tbe statement that Germany warmly welcomes this entente is doubted. Telegrams from Constantinople state that great interest is being displayed by the Palace in this subject as affecting the condition of the Armenians in Anatolia.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive bas delegated General Tbnr- neyesen Pacba. bis Higbnesb's A.D.C., to proceed to Austria to charter a steamer of the Austrian Lloydcompany to ooDvey the Khédivial family to Constantinople. After staying several days intheTurkish Capital his Highness will proceed by the same steamer to Europe, as already announced.

div.p: M. Naoom, delegate of the Ilellenio Government, and Az‘z Pacba Izz^t, Under-Sccretaty of State in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, are leaving to-day for Athens in connection with the commercial agreement which has been concluded between Egypt ai d Greece. The Greek colony in Cairo bavo given a banquet in honoar of M. Naoom.

div.head: L’EPARGNE IMMOBILIERE.
div.p: The "Journal do Caire” stated a few days ago that the Government had refused to sanction the formation of the company L’Epargne Immobilière. On enquiry, however, wo learn that this statement is unfoonded. The statutes of the company as well as of some others will not be examined till the next Council of Ministers.

div.head: “THE GEISHA” AT THE ALHAMBRA.
div.p: Before a house which was crowded in every part, the Lombardo Italian operetta company made their debut at the Alhambra Theatre yesterday evening with an Italian version of the popular mnsical comedy The Geisha. The company is not onknown to Alexandrian audiences, having visited this city previously, and the priuoipal artistes bave already gained a popularity which can only be enhanced by last night's performance. The prodaotion of The Geisha was in every re»prct sati factory— singing, maaio, staging, eto.

The ooly defect to an Englishman’s eye were one ot two rather grotesque military uniforms io which the naval (!) officers wore made to appear. Bot this is a mere detail : the many Englishmen who were present in the audience last night foimd little to criticise in the performance, which went with a swing from beginning to end. Sidney Jones’s music wasdone full justice to by an excellent orchestra under Big. Domenico Lombardo, and the various numbers received adequate treatment at the* hands of the company. S:grorina Bald', who is the possessor of a delightfolly fresh and pleasing voice, made a charming Mimosa San, and sang ber numbers very bweetly, evoking hearty applause, while Signoria Leoni was a bright and viva- cions Misa Mol'y Seamose. Signora Calltgaris, as Jaliette Diamante, sang well.

Big. Urbano was excruciatingly finny in the part of Wan Hi, k^Jping bis audience in a continual ripple of laughter, and Sig. Piraccini made an amusing bot witbal dignified Marcbese Imari. The other parti we-o all well filled, and the chorus was good. Special praise must be given to tbescenery and effects, which were appropriate and above the average. The oompany should bave a long and successful stay. The Geisha will bo repealed this evening.

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM
div.p: OPEN LETTER TO MUSTAPHA PACHA KAMEL

Excellency, — I have no derire to awaken painful' controversies, or to tronble you while engaged in the laborious task of explaining to the world in general the real completeness of the triomph of yonr Ruler.

I refer, of course, to hia Majesty of Yildiz. This task should empl >y your faculties to the utmost, and if you can persuade your followers of the truth of your contention yon will take rank with the sage lludibras, who, if I am rightly informed, could prove that black was white, and with Thrasyiuacbus, most renowood of sophists. At its completion yon will, I hope, be able to t-pare the time uecessary for an answer to certain questions which I am fain to put to yon, and which in my humble opinion deserve your attention.

First, I will ask yon what is year object t To restore Egypt to the Egyptians ? Do yoo speak of the Moalom majority, or of all the inhabitants of tbe coantry.Copt, Syrian, Moslem, and Jew alike Î If yoa speak of all, what imp ecsuaded yon to throw your pen into the balanco where:n the weights are graven with Pan-I^lamio mottoes I Did yon believe that the Europleana of Egypt, «he men who have aided yonr people and their rolers to make Bgypt prosperous, would lend yon their aid ?

Did yoa hope for the support of those Christians who were / Nationalists before you reaobed yoor years of indiscretion ? Or do yoa wish to restore Egypt to the 'forks ? Again, what is this new dootrine of Pan-Islamism î I infer, from my slight knowledge of Oriental history, that you desire to see all Moslems united in a political Whole bsne.vtb the beneficent rule of Hia Majesty Abdul Hamid II. But can you believe it possible that secular feuds and hatreds will set no obstacle to tbo accomplishment of yndr wish ?

Will the Moslems of India cast off infidel rale and depend on the 8nltan of /Room to defend them agaiust the Sikh and tho Qboorka, the Mahratta and tbe Rsjput 1 Will Shiah combine with Sunni ? Will the warriorSx.of Yemen and Nejd accept the rule oPthe Turk 1 Will European nations permit tbeqisoiples cf About Hoda and Izzet Pacba to drive them from their possessions !

If yon desire to see all Moslems acknowledge one spiritual bead, I fear you have a long road to travel. Troe, the Saltan bas in his keeping the sword and the standard of the Propbot.and at times prevents thé Bedouin from robbing the pilgrims whom devotion urges towards the Holy Places. But will the Afghan Emir, the Moorish Saltan, and the Arab Prince of Nejd acknowledge him as more than the first—among equals.

I do not discuss bis claims to the Caliphate ; I only wish to know who will accept them outside the limits of bis Empire I Thirdly—If yoo accept the Grand Tnrk as your master, I would ask you whother you see much to admire in bis role. Do yoqt approve of its accompaniments—the grinding taxation that is depopulating Syria, the* delation that makes every Moslem afraid to express his inmost thoughts, the corroption that poisor.a justice, the strange combination of niggardliness and profusion that robs the Empire of its wealth and is mi»uimed finance ?

Do yon—who claim to be impelled by progressive aud liberal ideas—admire the obscurantism that diecoaragea science, that opposes invention ? Have yon lived in any Ottoman provinoe far from the Capital that has be itched yon as fallen Romo bewitched all the world^and seen the conscripts dragged away shoeless, half-clothed, without doctors, without transport,^ die in the Yemen or serve without pay year in, year oot, in Macedonia or Kurdistan ?

There is a reverse side, remember, to the Ottoman medal. Lastly—I would say this in warning. I am no lover of there P§n-isma, Pan-Germanisrr, Pan-Slavism, Pan-Islamism, which lead to war and the last to the worst and craelest, to religioos watfare. Bot I have no desire to see the Moslem belief oppressed or its professors insolted and I recognise the tolerance of the British under whose rule or guidance Moslems need fear no persecution of their faith. Pan Iriamism comes many hondred years too late if it brings with it "holy” war against the infidel, if it metes out one justice to tbe Moslem and one to the Christian, if it approves of massacre and enslavement.

The idea of these horrors revolts you, but will it revolt the ignorant and the fana- t:cal to whom the doctrine calLi ? When all the world of Islam is equal, in justice, in chivalry, in civilisation, in tolerance with tbe Japanese whom you admire, Pan-Islamism will be possible, but where are 'he signs of progress towards that equality ? To me Pan- I-lamism means war and massacre. and the political overthrow of Islam, for if Islam binds itself together against Europe, the dissensions that have saved the last great Moslem State from de8trootion will cease and a new Jebad will provoke a new Crusade. Peace and education under honest rulers.—:tb»se aro the needs of the Moslem people». The patient needs tonics, your party offers him excitants and does not dream that there is any risk of bis becoming délirions. JULIUS.

div.head: AN OUTLAW'S END.
div.p: HALO MIRIAM KILLED.

Hailq Miriam, the raider who recently attacked a Takruri village in the Gedarif district/ has been attacked and slain by an Abyssinian chief, Glissa»sa, who was advancing with a force to co-operate with tbo Egyptian punitive column dispatched in parsoit of the ootlaw. Porty of Hailo Miriam’s captives have been recovered.
Gassassa is the Abyssinian officer in eatù' mand of the frontier diatriot. Hopes are entertained that all the prisoners take by Hailo Miriam will shortly be recovered.
SINAI BOUNDARY COMMISSION.

Kaimakam Owen Bey and Ibrahim Fatby Pacha, Egyptian members of the Boondary Commission, leave Cairo by the 6.15 p.m. train on Tharsday for Sort, cocompanied by Naoom Bey Shoukeir, secretary to the Commission. The pa ty will prooeed to Akaba in H.H. gonboat Noor el- Bahr.
In the absence of Miralai Owen Bey, Kaimakam Parker Bey will act as Direotor of Intelligence at Ca;ro.,Parker Bey, who bas left El Arisb for Cairo, bas been replaced there by Abmed Bey Tewfik.
THE NILE FLOOD

As our readers will realise from the Nile gauges which we poblish to day, there is so far every reason to be satisfied with the summer water supply. The Blue Nile has carried a good bead of water and the result is well shown, in the figures of the first five days of the month for Berber, which average 1 m. 054, while in 1905 the average of the correeçond- in^five days was 0.754.

div.head: CYPRUS MAIL CONTRACT.
div.p: Our Limassol Correspondent writes - A mail çontraot has at last be*n conclude), and the stigma attaching to the Island io having no regular mail service has been removed. The contract has teen granted to the Limarsil Steamship Co, the subsidy being, it is said, between £4,500 and £',000. It is to be hoped that the arrangement will work satisfactorily. The Moss Steamship Co. has bought up the old Bell Line, and we shall expeot to see the familiar vessels of the latter loading cargo at our ports as before, but with greater regularity.

A Greek vessel, the Irioi, now calls every ten days at Limassol, and tbenoe proceeds to Port Said, Alexandria, and Piraeus. It should prove a useful additional means of oommuni- cation between Cyprus and Bgypt.

div.head: MORALITY IN EGYPT.
div.p: THE BANE OF THE CAPITULATIONS

"Evangelical”(Cairo) writes:—The following flections have suggested themselves to ms r ftfr reading a work by M. de Goerville entitled /Ntw Eyy^t.” In nting- the above title it /should be borne in mind that I am considering a subject quite apart from that of Egyptian morality, which distinction, far from being one without a differeooe.ia a very important cne. The moral qualities of the Egyptian people are very ably dealt with by Lane in Chapter XIII. ( ’Character”) of his well known work "Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians," and what he wrote of the inhabitants of this conntry more than half a century ago equally applies to the natives of the present day,so litt'e do these old-time countries change in so comparatively short a period.

When l ate the term "Morality in Bgypt” I rofor to that of the many foreigners who ni live in Bgypt or visit the coontry dariug thi. winter season, one phase o£ which is very prominently dealt with in a bcok that has of late attracted considerable notice in Europe and in the United Stitoi, as well as in Egypt The American newspapers have been publishing extrecs from M. do Gaerville’s "New Egypt” which yoa reviewed a few months ago, and one of the leading papers, "The Boston Herald,” confesses itself unable to determine if the abandon both of men and w^mrn described by the anthor is an Egyptian! characteristic, or if Eoglnh, French, and-Ame- rican tourists are not responsible for mcch of the bad odoor of Cairo and Alexandria. I may say at once that I think it matter for regret that M. de Gaerville showed himself so reoeptive respecting information of a scindait in nature.

There is so moch in the book that is of real interest—for example, his deocription of tbeKhedive’s farming operation», —that it is a pity that ib tbould be disfigured by so much scandalous gossip, which may do harm in many ways, thongb perhaps it may serve a good pnrpos*.in helping to bring into prominence the damage done to tho cause cf pnblic morality by the continued existence of the Capitnlations and the abuses wh ch they, and they alone, render possible.

In spite of Lord Cromer’s Report, I see at present no sign of any movement for their modification, either in the direction of a strong expression. of public opinion or of official aotion. Sorely it is time that some decided protest was made against the further continued exercise of powers which in the present day coold well be dispensed with.

It is greatly to be regretted that a keener sense of responsibility is not felt by foreign residents in Egypt. Their noncbalence alone renders possible' the existence of each hotbeds of vice as the "Fishmarket” in Cairo and the “Garden” in Alexandria. Snob plagoe spots should be rutblossly dealt with in the first instance, and their cleaning followed by the resolnte suppression of gambling bells, places for the sale of adulterated- foreign liquor», and the system of frand under which inferior brands are sold under forged trade labe*8. We kr ow what can be done by what is accompliskei in the matter of'hashish ; fortunately for Egypt, hashish smoking is not indulged in by Europeans, ,so that it does not oome under the ægia of the Capitalationa and measures for the suppression of theAraffio are not hampered by foreign interference The general impression left on the mind of the reader of "New Egypt” is that the wonderful pro’perity to te seen on every hand in E/ypt brings with it, instead cf an abatement of immorality, a most undesirable lowering of a standard of public morality that has never been high.

If this goes on, and bas really attained the proportions assigned to it by M. de Gaerville, respectable tourists will shun this country, and wanderers in Bible lands will confine themselves to Palestine, Syria, and other places where vice is not so openly flaunted. On the ;other hand the roué, the gambler, the drunkard will xbe encouraged to oome in order to indulge freqly. in practices t hat other countries with their better regulated codes of morality, do all in their power to pot a stop to. On every band we hear of extended arrangements for the oonveyance of tourists to Bgypt, increased facilities naturally bciogiog a large number of visitors every succeeding year Fresh discoveries constantly reveal the grandeurs of the bygone ages and bring abont the desire to learn more of these mementoes of the past than can be gleaned from the pages of books which in their turn greatly help to whet the appetites of their reidere.

But if Egypt is to gain the reputation of being a country that is conducive to moral laxity and where a free in- dnlgenoe of licentiousness is possible, a strong deterring intloence will be created against bringing wives at d families into such undesirable oonditiqns. The Bobjpot.cf morality is a Urge one. It is an accepted axiom that yoa cannot make a nan sober by Act of Parliament.

Neither can legislative enactments make a man moral. But while the individual has liberty to formulate bis own oode of morality and aot upon it, tbe oolleotive action of the oommunity may be so framed that at least it offers no encouragement to vice and removes tempta- tation from the path of tbe weak. And this is the oourse that I hope will be adopted by the Egyptian Government when the. great impediment to aotion is oleared from its path and foreigners bvoome subjsot*to the laws of the land in which they sojourn.

THE NATAL REVOLT.
PROBABLE EMPLOYMENT OF IMPERIAL TROOPS.
PIETERMARITZBURG, May 22.

General Stephenson has arrived here en route for Zululand in order to study the military operations. His visit is considered significant in view of the probability of the employment ofImperial troops. (reuter.)
Durban, may 22.
The columns are making huge hauls od cattle, but the rebels are successfully avoiding encounters. (reuters.)

div.head: THE EDUCATION BILL
div.p: THREATENED NONCONFORMIST REVOLT.
LONDON, MAY 22.

The government are threatened with the revolt of their noncomformists supporters if they make concessions in respect of the "Extended Facilities" clause of the Education Bill, for which anoother influential section of Liberals are pressing.Meetings of the various opposing Liberal groups are constantly being held with a view to exercising pressure on the Government. The measure entered the commiittee stage yesterday. (Reuter.)

div.head: TSAR AND DUMA
div.p: St. Petersburg, May 22.
The DUma received the President's notification of the Tsar's decision calmly, and agreed that it was the substance of the address which was of importance, and not the manner of delivery. (Reuter).

div.head: GREEKS IN ROUMANIA
div.p: Bucharest, May 22

Owing to the murders of Wallachs by Greek hands in Macedonia, Roumaniahas expelled 23 Greek docotrs and merchants belonging to secret organizations and proposes to subject all Greeks to a special regime. (Reuter.)

div.head: AUSTRIA AND HUNGARY
div.p: BUDAPEST, MAY 22.

The speech from the Thorne congratulates itself on the cessation of misunderstanding. It hopes that all legislators will henceforth act in keeping with the freely expressed will of the country. (Havas.)

div.head: KAISER AND PRINCE VON BULOW
div.p: BERLIN, MAY 22.
The Emperor William has written to Prince von Bulow expressing gratitude for his services and hoping that they may be retained for the benefit of the German Nation. (Reuter.)

Cricket. Lets. Yorkshire v. Leicestershire. Yorkshire won by an innings and 103 runs. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE LATE LORD CURRIE
div.p: The late Lord Carrie began life as a clork o,t pro'taticn at the Foreign Office in 1854, when he was twenty years of age; he had not long to wait before Teoeivi'g interesting employment, as, only a couple of years later, he was temporarily attached to the British Embassy at St. Petersburg. In December, 1*68, when the dispute between Denmark and Prussia about the JElbe Duchies bad reached the acute stage which p’eceded theoatbrotk of hostilities, bo accompanied Lord Wodehouse to Copenhagen ou a special mission to the Coart if Kiog Christian. He remained io the Danish capital through the opening weoks of tho Schleswig Hoistein war, in fact, till the shipwreck of tho London Conference, by which a settlement was attempted, returning home in Jane, 1861.

In 1867 he assisted in the protoool department at the conference of the Powers, held in London, to settle the status of Luxembourg, which, after the dissolution of the Germanic Confederation, Louis, Napoleon bad wished to purohase. The meeting resulted io an agreement guaranteeing the neutrality of the Grand Duchy, and requiting the withdrawal of the Prussian garrisop. With so thorough a training in the rough waters ol diplomacy, it was not surprising that Mr. Carrie wsh in 1876 selected as tenetary by tho late Marquis of Sdiebiry daring hit special embassy to Constantinople to attempt to compose the differences between Tarksy and Roasia, which had just taken one of theii periodic tarns for the worse.

Mr. Currie and Ml M. Corry, afterward* Lord Rowton, wore joint secretaries to the British representatives at the momentous-deli berations at which the Treaty of. San Stefanr was recast. He continued, to act'as Lord Salis bury’s private secretary till-1880, anti in the meanwbi'o had charge of the correspondence with regard to Cyprus, which island Lore] Beaconeficld had brought bask with him in hie pocket from Berlin. Io 1881 he perfo med the 'duties of secretary to the Marquis of Northampton’s special mission, which wa^ sent to Spain to invest King Alfonso with the Order of the Garter, and in 1884 he was joint'proto oolist to the Lcndoa Conference on Egyptian finances. Sir Philip Carrie, as he had non become,was appointed in 1869 to the important position of Permanent Undersecretary fot Foreign Affairs, and while in occupation of thia post was one if the delegates to whom was re ferred the settlement of the frontier between Datch territory and the British Protectorate in Berne.

In Janaary, 1694. Sir Philip was once more at Constantinoplo, bat this time at her Majesty’s Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary. The position of the British representative, always one of great responsibi lity and difficulty, was rendered fifty times more so by the stormy events of the ensuing years. Sir Philip Carrie was in England during August, 1896,when the seizure of the Ottoman Bank by the Armenian revolutionary committee was sncceedod by the slaughter of some five or six thousand of their coreligionists.

He returned to find political confneion worse confounded. Armenians and members of the Young Turkey party were beiog relentlessly hunted down. Efforts to secure something like j istice for these anbappy people occupied the attention of the ambassador till the Cretan Q 'estioa became acute, act Other matters were momentarily thrown into the shade by the ontbrsak, in 1897, of the Greoo-Turkish war. Finally, he was in 1898 transferred to Roms. Six months later he was raised to the poqraj/a as Biron Currie, of Hawley, in the cannty of Southampton. In January, 1903. he retired on a pension.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL TRAFFIC
div.p: Mr. Consul-General Cameron, in his report on the trade and shipping at Port Said for the past year, states :— 4.116 vessel* of a net tonnage of 13.131,105 tons passed through the Canal in 1905, as compared with 4,237 vessels of 13,401,835 tons in 1904, showing a decrease of 121 vessels and 267,730 tons. Of these,116 vessels, 2,954 were merchant vessels, 823 mail steamers, 162 warships, transports, .and Government-chartered Vessels, and 177 ships in ballast. .The transit receipts were 1P,829.667 fr. as against 115.733,607 fr, in 1904, a decrease of 1,903.940 fr.

The mean net tonnage has risen from 1,000 tons in 1871 to T.500 tons in 1880 to 2,000 tons in 1890, to 2,800 tons in 1900, to 3.163 tons in 19 4, and to 3,191 tons in 1905. The mean duration t f transit remains about the ramp, namely.’ 18 hours for al’ vessels ; bat the general effective rate for mail steamers is 15 hours The use of the electric light-practically universal, amounting to 96 per cent. “Out of a total of 4 116 vessels, 2,484 were British, a decrease of 195 as compared with 1904.

The British net tonnage was 8,356,910 tons, a decrease of 476,989 tone as compared with 1904. The British percentage in number of vessels is 60.4 and in tonnage 63 6. There figures apply only to the general total, but if we consider only merchant vessels, the British percentages have steadily risen do ring the last five years, f.om 67 to 74 pe- cent, in number and from 71 to 77 per cent, in net tonnage. During the last four years the Gorman percentage in number of ships has risen from 13 to 14 .6 percent and their tonnage from Po to 16 per went. France, the Netherlands Austria Hungary, Italy, and Norway combined famish a total of 19.1 percent. of the vessels and 16.7 per cent, of the tonnage.

While British shipping may be said to be holding its own, the leading German lines of steamers are showing great- enterprise. Their mail and passenger ships are increasing in sire, their companies appear to be remarkably well managed, and to pay good dividends, and one of them in particular, the Hausa, is constantly represented in this port.

div.head: NOTES FROM CYPRUS
div.p: WEATHER AND HARVEST
LAND ALLOTMENT COMPANYS OPERATIONS
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Laruaca, May 14.

There has been an unsaual amount of gri y, cloudy weather for aocr.e tine past and a rain-, fall, rather exceptional for the time of year, has boon experienced o\er the greater part of the Island daring the last few weeka. The barley harvest has consequently, to some extent, been à interfered with, but a good quantity is now on the threshing floors. The Government steam threshing machine will shortly commence operations. Two steam threshers have jast been imported by the Anglo Egyptian Land Allotment Co.

The proceedings of this company have been, for some time past, the topic of conversation and have been followed with great interest by all classes of the community. For the first time during its more recent history Cyprus finds herself being exploited and opened npby capitalists, and whatever may be the ultimate outcome, there can be no doubt that doing the last few months those who htve had eligible properties for sale bave, many of them, been able to dispose of them at first rato figures. Those properties, which have passed in*o the hands of the company, are now to be developed, and I hear that large consignments of up-to-date agricultural machinery and tools are now on their way. This introduction of modern implements of husbandry is just what is required to enable the native peasant to reform his present primitive methods.

The Government is not in the best position for condaoting trade operations, and beyend keeping.a small stock of such implements and recommending their use and demonstrating their advantages by employing them on their own lands, they cannot well go. A few wealthy farmers can do much more than the Government to Umiliarizs the natives with such tools, and Cyprus may foel grateful to the Laud Allotment Co. for what it is doing in this respect.

div.head: Properties Acquired
div.p: Among the properties acquired by it is that belonging to the Eastern and Colonial Association at Colossi. This property, which is aboot . 700 acres in extent, has the two groat advan- ! tages of havir g an excellent water apply, and of being within 7 miles of Limassol port. The ^ association has been actively engaged during the last few years in transplanting carob trees and olive trees ; also in panting mulberry trees, and these all preseut a very floorisbing appearatca. It was somewhat tf an experiment to transplant the carob trees, but it has proved eminently saocessfol ; the failures being only abotit 3% to 5% among some thousands. Several of the trees are now grafted. The association has also turnod its attention latterly to sericulture, and has been successful in noting,fairly large numbers of worms and in obtaining a good .yield of cocoons. This is an indostiy that is particalar'y adaptable.to Cyprnsr and I trust that the change of ownership will stimulate it still more and lead to its farther extension in that neighbourhood.

div.head: Cases of Rabies
div.p: Some cases of rabies have been recently reported in the Island. A notice has therefore been issued by the Municipality of Nicosia calling upon ail owuers cf dogs to keep them under control and to give them collars, and intimating that all ownerless dogs lound straying will be poisoned by the Municipal authorities and Police. The notice is infoxoe till the 31st May.

div.head: Dance at english Club.
div.p: On the 12th instant a dance was given by the small Rnjli h community and the officers of the Inniskillings at the English Club. On the same day a Gymkhana was held on the Polo Ground, Nicosia, which drew a number of entries and attracted a largo gathering. The afternoon was the fir est for some time past.

div.head: Commissioner's House Burnt.
div.p: A fire broke out last week at Aspocremno, the Trobdos residence of Mr.C. Wodehouse, Commissioner of Papho. A considerable portion of the house was burnt down, but fortunately some of the furniture was saved.

div.head: Expulsion of Jews.
div.p: The Legislative Council ended their latoors on the 4th instant. Notice has b*en given that a law tb to be introdneed in the next session by a native member, fo provide for the expulsion of Jews from Cyprus and to probi- bitJLheir entry into the Island. Its provisiors are mediaeval ior their ferocity.

div.head: Hotels for Tourists
div.p: Rumours continne to be heard of the erection of hotels throughout the Island. When these are established and tourists sre swarming here we may expect to fee a sharp rise in the price of commodities generally, which have already more than doubled their value in gome instances of recent years. How those with fixed incomes. Government officials and others, will then manage to exist at all, unless their incomes or salaries are considerably increased, is a problem. Indeed, it is a very ferions one at the present time

div.head: Personal
div.p: Captain A. H. Young, C.M.Ü., who is shorttly leaving Cyprus on appointment as Colonial Secretary, Straits Settlements, is now on leave in the Island. Colonel Gore is acting as Chief Secratary
Mr.C.M.Georgiades of the Chief Secretary's Office, has been appointed Traffic Manager of the Cyprus Government Railways.

div.head: THE COTTON WORM
div.p: INTERESTING NOTE
The following is the text of a note by the Entomologist of the Khédivial Agricultural Sooiety on tbo E/yptian Cotton “Boll Worm.'* (Earias Ineulane, Boisdoaal) : —

This pest annually causes very serions loss to the cotton crop during the months of August, September and October, by boring into the young flower beds and the ripening bolls,causing them to die or to open premature If, the result being that the fibre does cot mature properly.

During the past rosson it has been estimated that tho less from the ravagea ot this inaoot bas been considerably more than one million pounds aterliog ; it is therefore evident that the question of the bollworm is a most important one, and merits the close attention of all engaged in tbo cultivation of cotton in this country. The following brief acccunt of (his post Ins -been wiitton with a view to awakeuiog tho interest of the cultivators, and enlightening them with regard to its life- history and habits. Tbo Bhort descriptions will also enable them to recognise the species.
Description, Life History, and Habits.

The parent of the bollworm is a small moth, known scientifically as Earias insuhna, Bois- du va), which has the following appearance :— Wing oxpanse 22mm. Head, fore part of body (thorax), and followiog-, bright peagreen in colour. Hind wing* white. Hind part of body silvery grey in colour.
There is another form of this species which has the head, thorax and forewings yellow in colour.
These moths may frequently be found at lest on the leaves of cotton plants, or they poay be seen on tbo wing when disturbed by a person walking through a cotton field.

The female moth lays a small, round,blueish- green egg on the boll, generally in one of the grooves near the apex. As a rule only one egg is laid on a boll, bat a single female is capable of producing* over two hundred eggs. Opposition aho takes place on the young flower-bads. After three or four day3 tho egg hatches and gives rise to a small caterpillar or bollworm whtch measure* only just over 1mm.; consequently it is very, easily overlooked at this stage. After emerging from tho egg the young bollworm bores its why into the boll throngh a tiny hole. Havinggair el an entranco it feeds for a few days on tho insido of the shell, but ’ as it grows older ar d larger it makes its way ! to the seeds and devours their contents. Tire fibre or cotton is also bitten and stained by the excrement of bollworm, to that it is quite spoiled.

The effect of the attack on the bolls differs according to their size and age.If a very young bud or boll is attacked, the involucre opens wide and the bud finally dies and falls from the plant, but before death takes place the larva leavea the bud and proceeds to attack a healthy one. When a large or medium siV.il gjeen boll is invaded by a boll- worm it opons prematurely and the fi* re does not spread oat, but remains iu a matted lock. The bolls cm be easily recognized, and if they are examined carefully, the hole by which the bollworm entered can be seen.

Sometimes a boll which has been attacked does not open at all and turns to a bright red or redcih brown colour'these are tbo bolls known as HMabroom.” When examined they will be seen to have been pierced by a bollworm. The presenco of a bollworm in a green boll can be detected by the ronud hole in ttie shell of the boll, and by the quantity cf excrement, thrown oat by the Ifyrva, which collects aronnd the entrance. Before the bollworm becomes full grown it may destroy several bolls or lads. The mature bollworm is very characteristic,and can readily be identified by anyone who will take the trouble to cat open an infested green boll.

The larva is aboot 15mm. long, and is of a rodduh brown or'greeuish oolour with pale dark markings. The body is covered with numerous fleshy Hpiko-liko prominences which are longest and most conspicuous near the head." This character enables this larva to be distinguished from all other species of larvæ foond on cotton

To reach céaturity the bollworm requires about fifteen days ; it then leaves the boll and spins a small cocoon of white or brown coloored silk between the side of tho bo’l and the invohere, or on other parts of tho plant. The cocoon is somowhat * boat-shaped and inside it the larva turns to the pupa which is approximate’)' 9mm to 10mm in length.
After ten days or a fortnight the pupa gives rise to the adult moth which, if a female, will again lay eggs on the ootton. and thus give rise to another generation of bollworms.

There are a large number of generations of this insect during tho cot on season. The first generation, which is a very small one, appears on tbe cotton at tbctenrlof. May and the beginning of Jane. The famatee which give rife to there first bollworms lay their eggs on the terminal shoots for a distance of from one to three inches. The leaves on the invaded shoot droop and the whole of the attacked portion finally dies and turns bUck. When the flower bads and bolls appear thry are attacked in preference to the shoots.

By September and October the bollworm, which has been breoding in cotton s;nce the end of May, is naturai'y very numerous and causes vo y ferions i» j »iy. At this time fogs are very prevalent and all the damage that the bollworm caijeeKKitbarto has been attributed to them This'ddca is quite incorrect, as a? y one can vrrUy for hinue’f if ho will examine thebolls vjhich aro supposed to have been damag«d by fog.. In the great majority it eases these bolls have been pierc-d by bolUorro. The attack can bo recognized from tho round hoTe in the shell, and tonnels will be found in the - matted fibre; the seeds will aho h kve boon j art ally or entirely devoured.

During fho winter the bollworm fieds on any cotton which has been left standing in the field, also on secohd sboots.of “til" and "Bamia" The garden hibiscus aho aflords a food plant to this species durirg the winter, tbe boll wot ms feeding inside the buds

div.head: ARABIC NAMES IN SERAPION
div.p: TO THE EDITORR OF THE “Egyptian GAZETTE.” Sir,—Those of your readers interested in Arabic learning and literature will desire to per a now treatise by Dr. Pierre Guignes, of the Faculty of Medicine of Beyrout, upon "Les noms Arabes dans Sdrapion : Libor do Simplici Medirina," published ly the Paris Imprimerie Nationale This serapion, called The Yrounger,M flourished in the 12th century and his work was translated and printed at Vonioe in 1497. Probably this Latin translation was from a Hobrow version of the Arabie original. The Latin translation of Arabie terms is mo3t barbarous, and the tracing back of them to the original semitio names by Dr. Guigaes is an example of pains and erudition. They are chiefly titles ol plants, minerals and animals, but many of them are recognisable in modern Arabio and are need by Eastern pharmacists: Dr. Guignes examines some 550 namoa, giving a complete Arabio index and commentary on each of much value.
Joseph Offord

div.head: The Telephone Company of Egypt
div.p: Limited.
Communications telephoniques entre la ville du Caire et celle de Tantah

Les Abonnés de la Telephone Company et Je Publie sont informés que l’Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat vient do construire une ligue téléphonique entre le Caire et Tantah quisera exploitee des le Juin 1906.

Los Abonnés pourront communiquer direct* meut par leurs appareils du domioile ou du bureau sur les réseaux de la Telephone Company of Egypt Ltd. à partir de 7 heures du matin jusqu’à minuit Pour ceux qui désirent communiquer avec Alexandrie voie Caire, et en attendant que l'Administration des Chemins de fer fisse courir une liguo directe reliant Tantab à Alexandrie, la Telephone Company a é’.abli l'horaire provisoire suivant :

Les communications pourront se transmettre aussi pondant loi autres heures de la journée au cas où les lignes Caire-Alexandrie seront libres. Ceux qui n'ont pas le téléphone pourront s’en servir de la Cabine Publique établie dans les Bureaux do notre Agence Téléphonique de Tan tah.

D’Alexandrie et du Caire, ils pourront a’en servir do3 Cabines déjà établies à cet effet. La taxe ci-après *eera appliquée pour les communications tant de Tantah au Cairo que de Tantah au Caire que do Tantah à Alexandrie (voie Caire) et vice-veraa : Pour ohaquo 3 minutas ou fraotion do 3 minutas T.TT5.

Pour plus do 3 mlnutos Jusqu’à 6 minutes P. T. 10. Aucune communication ne devra^aépa*ser les 6 minutes à moins quo la ligne lo soit libre, dans ce car, la conversation pourra continuer à raidon do F. T. 5 pour chaque 3 minutes ou fraction.

Les demandes seront régulièrement enré- gistrées et les communications accordées à tour d’inscription. Un service qrgeut sera établie contre paiement d’une triple taxe. Afin d'éviter des délais et de* complications, Messieurs les Abonnés sont priés d’effectuer par anticipâtiv n un dépôt nen inférieur à la somme de P. T. ICO.

Avant l'extinction de ce dépôt, un avis sera envoyé à l’Abonné le priant de le renouveler. La Telephone Company of Egypt Limited fO mot à la disposition des Abonnés et du Public pour tous les renseigoemeots complémentaires.
G.C.STEVENSON
27988-1 Director General.

div.head: THE SULTAN AND EGYPT.
div.p: HOME PRESS ON THE SETTLEMENT

The announcement 4 that the Sultan had acceded to the British demands was received with great satisfaction by the Press at home, and the success of Sir Edward Grey s diplomacy is the snbject of goneral congratulation; at the same time the hand ot Lord Cromer is thoroughly recognised, by these who know Egypt We append a f«w of the leading commenta:—
"TIMES."

The Sultan, who is a man of great shrewdness, when he allows his powers of judgment fair play, can hardly fail to draw some useful conclusions from tho signal and conspicnons failure of his foolish attempt to “bluff" this country. He is much too clearsighted not to realize bow complete aud humiliating that failnre has been, and how serious is the blow which it must indict upon his prestige, not only iu Egypt, but throughout the Mahemedan world.

He must bitterly regret by this time that be flung down to us a challenge which he has been compelled to withdraw, and that he has demonstrated in this way that in no circumstances can it bo well for discontented Mahemedans to put their trost in him. No ingenuity can hide from them the fact that he has tried a fall with England and that he has been badly worsted in it.

Some of them at Cairo, who occupy very High stations, were undoubtedly encouraged by his agents, and even by his High Commissioner, to take part in very dangerous intri guea. They now find themselves deserted, and it may be tbat when the whole story has been unravelled, they will disoover that the interests of his confederates are tho very last matter with which Abdul Hamid concerna h:mself, when he is dfficaltiea himself Now that the hot fit is ovsr, he must perceive that, if he wore to persist in meddling in Egypt, be might indeed cause ns some trouble, but that, when that trouble was over, it is not we who would have left Egypt for good.

We are coûtent to recognize Dominai suzerainty so long as he does not attempt to use it as an engir o to utdormine the British cccupation. But if ho wcrp to provoke a conflict, it is the shadow, end net the substance, which would disappear in the struggle. There is another conseqoence of this episode on which he cannot reflect with satisfaction. He has demonstrated that no Power was ready to back his quarrel, while not only France, but Russia, Frances ally, warmly supported ooj attitude against him. That is a phenomenon which bo may ponder with advantage.

Referring to the evil influerce exerofsed by Izzet Pacha tbe“Times” says: Nothirghas done more to hart the larger interests of the Ottoman Empire, as the more lagaciooeof the Turkish statesmen themselves recognize, than tbe disastrous influence which ignorant and ambitious favourites like Izzjt Pacha have acquired over foreign affairs. It is eminently desirable, both in the tree interests c f Turkey and io the interests of those European Powers who really wish her wel1, that this influence should be destroyed. The remedy is in the hands of the Ambassadors at Constantinople and of their Governments.
"DAILY TELEGRAPH"

The result is a signal reastertion of the reality of British power in the heart of the East ; it is a blew which cats through the web of pan Inlamio intrigue, which bad recently begun to threaten the vital interests of every European Power with a Moba- medan dominion ; it is a warning, to all whom it may concern, that a new spirit has been established in. this country, in spite of all superficial signs to the contrary ; and that party changes have become powerless at last to weaken the unity and determination of British policy when there is question of d. fending the interests of this Empire against foreign aggression; and the effect will be felt through out the whole of Islam.

It is a further cry than the Sultan and his mischievous advisers bad reckoned on, from Algecires to Sinai. . . Henceforth, England in Egypt stands on guard for two purposes. Placrng the peninsula of Sinai atd a hundred miles of the noithern wilderness between the SuEz Canal and the new and formidable machinery for mobilisation with whiob the Ottoman Empire wiM be ultimately provided, she protects her position as the gTeateit of all Mohamedan Powers, and defends the rights cor ferred upon her by the unsurpassed works of constructive statesman- I hip which she has accomplished singlehanded in the interests of the Egyptian people.

He condly, the British regime upon the Nile is a new guarantee for the interests of civilisation at large in the pan Islamic sphere—for the safety of the Mihamedan Empire if France, and of the Moslem territories ol tbe Tsar. Our role in Egypt is now the keystone which could

not be dislodged without ruin to the whole fabric of Western ii flaenoe on the further shores of the Mediterranean, and throughout the Aeiatio East British sea-power runs through the centre of the pan-Islamio world, dividing that vast sj here into two halves. It is useless for Yildiz to dream of reconquering Cairo, as of replacing the Crescent upon Gibraltar, wbere.it once waved; and the Sultan baa leavnod nothing from the Tabah dispute, if be has not learned that a continued attempt to work against this country can only end in provoking a worte requol than tho punishment he has narrowly avoided, and in bringing the whole elaborate fabric of his late policy to the ground.
"STANDARD"

In standing stiffly upon our diplomatic rights it most not be suppose 1 that we have inflicted an unnecessary humiliation upon the Sultan. To the mind of Oriental statecraft there id no shame in yielding to compnlsior, whereas Ablul Hamid and his Ministers wonld have thought themselves disgraced if they had listened to mere reason and justice. They hud been playing for a diplomatic triumph as well as frr a territorial aggrandisement.

If Great Britain had not both made a display of overpowering naval forces and convinced them that it meant to use its strength, they would have magnified their success throughout the Modem orld, and would also have proceeded to carry out their aggressive schemes against the Kho- diviate. The design was quite well understood by Lord Cromer, who has once again proved his patience and tact iu dealing with Orientals. He waited until the Sultau'a agents had put themsehei clearly and demopstrably in the wrong.

The occupation of the Tabah district was an indefensible violation of the territory which we are pledged to protect and the clandestine removal of boundary stones and telegraph poles was just sucji an act ot trickery ns destroys what nright have been vamped up into a plausible case.
"WESTMINSTER GAZETTE"

It was essential to us that tho Sultan should not take advantage of any vagUeneSS as to I ho exact line to “jump thE claim" to Tabah and to insinuate further claims over the Sinaitio Peninsula. It is essential that Egypt shaM retain har hold over tho Peninsula and tin desert.

But, subject to these main objects, it is comparatively immaterial whether the line is drawn a few miles to the east or a few miles to the west. What we peek is a definite boundary recognised by all parties which will prevent these encroachments in future and enable os to watch tho progress of the Herj»z Railway without the constant apprehension that it will suddenly be given a sinister strategical aspect by unauthorised attempts to push a branch line across the desert. We are told this morning that the Porte, being headed off in this direction, will show greater zeal than ever in extending the main linesouth into Arabia towards Medina and Mecca.

Let us say again that we have no hostility towards this enterprise. On the contrary, as a Mohamedan Power, we are friendly to any effort which makes it easier for the pilgrims to reach Mecca; and it is greatly to be desired that the experts who enlarge on this subject in London newspapers will be careful to give no handle to fanatics, in Cairo or elsewhere, whose objects it is to represent us as hostile to the pilmgrimage.

div.head: EGYPTIANS AND TURKS
div.p: The bulk of the Egyptian population have become for too prosperous under British rule, and remember for too well the oppressions of the old regime, to desire that we should make way for the Turk.Egypt again, is too near Syria, and there are too large a number of Syrian immigrants, for the Egyptian population to have any illusions as to what government under Torkiah influences moans. But thoogh wo are convinced that the Egyptians themselves will never try to aubstituteTurkish for British rcle, wo most not forgot that they are essentially a passive people, and that their attitude is always to accept any ruler who can got himself into the saddle.

It is probably a safe, role never to expect gratitude from subject races; but oven if the Egyptians felt gratitude for what wo havo done for thorn, wo may bo sure that ihoy would not show it by resisting the Turks. They would regret os when we had goro, but they would not lift a finger to provont our expulsion. Therefore, small ard contempt ble as is the Turkish faction in Cairo, and unwilling as the Egyptians would be to be despoiled by tbo Turks, we shall no doubt be wine to take security that the Sultan shall not have an emissary in Cairo whose main business- qadermine our position Ths Sultan, in our opinion, should be told that he must withdraw the High Commissioner, and that ifhe refuses to do the, wo shall have to reconsider tho whole ot those nominal relations in which Egypt stands to the Turkish Empire. (“The Spectator").

div.head: EGYPTIAN MUMMIES
div.p: AMERICAN FAKES.
NO GENUINE EGYPTIAN DEAD MAN IN AMERICA
A LIMA MAN'S SCHEME
LOS ANGELES, (CAL.)

There is not a single Egyptian mummy in the United States, not even excepting the famous 'mummies’ for which the Smithsonian Institution has paid thousands of dollars. I make this statement from SO years of experience with the relics, curios and monstrosities of the museums of the world, and will accept any challenge backed by money to prove it" In his sombre laboratory at 525 South Spring street^ Professor J. R Fisher made the above startling statement. Professor Fisher has Tong, been supposed to be a clever taxidermist, a naturalist anatomist and maker of wax figures no thing more.

He is getting old, is this cunning imitator of the dead, and he consents to betray himself to his fellow men. He is not ashamed of his calling. He reasons that, as he never exhibited his work, and has never conducted a museum, he is innocent of obtaining money under falso pretences, the museum proprietor, says Professor Fisher, is guilty.
SCIENTISTS DECEIVED

Until now many learned scientists, naturalists and savants have laboured under the sweet delusion that much which they have seen is genuine, and even after reading the confessions of the professor they may continue ta doubt his story. His mummies and many other manufactured freaks are to-day on exhibition as genuine and original in the National Museum of France, in the London Skrand Museum, and in numerons other national exhibition halls of the Old World. Professor Fisher in the manufacture of tve Egyptian mommy mes human tooth —frequently procured from dentists—and human bones procured from surgical colleges.
With this genuine frame for a ground work, he manufactures the dried and wrinkled "flesh" (a perfect imitation of Egyptian embalmer's effect) from the actual basis of carnal substances.

A real mummy, when chemically analyzed resolves to a basis of animal glucose. In order that his work may stand this test, he emplys that basis using glucose and cotton batting thus defying scientific scepticism, should it exist in this particular. The cotton, under any alchemic acid leaves the material atomic ingredient of skin and tissue which is nothing more than the base substance of clay. Here again a test fails to detect the fraud.

div.head: STAND EVERY TEST
div.p: From the various abattoirs he procures such entrils and other organs as can be preserved by his process of embalming and then shapes them so they will conform to human organs. There is a nothing lacking in his mummies.Though a creation of cotton, glucose and paier mache, they stand every conceivable test. Professor Fisher learned the secrets of his weird art in far Berlin, where as a taxerdermit he became well known to the naturalists of Germany. He is the man whi superintended the mounting of the famous elephant Jumbo.

professor Fisher supplies many of the greatest freaks of mummies sold and exhibited by the wolrd's dealers.Who has not seen “the pug dog child, born in Cleveland, Ohio, and the elephant child," and the “alligator-boy," and the 4 family of of mummified Aztecs, exhibited all over America as having been on- earthed fo the ancient ruins of Anahoac None of these things have ever existed, declares the professor, and be admits having created and sold them to the men who are still reaping harvests from their exhibitions. The “mermaid," the giant “Newfoundland octopus," exhibited at the world's fair— these are other of bis freak productions, every one of which endures tbe test of acid, fire and water.

div.head: NO GENUINE MUMMIES
div.p: “You ask me," he said, 'If I believe there are ary gennir e mommies in America. I have seen them all, and I say emphatically, there are none. There are no mommies in Egypt except of the royal family, for others could not afford the embalming prooess used to the bat art. “While in the Smithsonian institution at Washington,said Professor Fibber loathe writer, “aw countless mummified objects and curious, freaks and war relics which I recognized as of my own handiwork.

The metallic quirt ard the saddle supposed to luvo been tho property or Napoleon, now exhibited in the Louvre in Paris, are others of my works. “I manofictqre old flint-lock guns, swords, Indian; Persian, Chinese, Japanese, Egyptian and old world relics, pottery, vases, nrns, quoits, spears, beads, bracelets, and Sanscrit

div.head: THE OHIO PETRIFIED MAN.
div.p: “In Lima, OhIo, a few years ago, a man , camn to me one night and asked for a perfect petrified man—one that wonld endnre all tests. It was buried just below the surface 1 of tho gronnd. The discovery of the supposed, to-be petrified man by a ploughman resulted Great was the excitement. Perhaps yon remember about, it. The papers were full of it : scientists and professors from all over the, land bartered to the scene of the discoveiy and never was a collection of people so badly fooled

div.head: THE NATIVE'S TEETH
div.p: WHY ARE THEY SO GOOD?

The European in Egypt qonscions of the scrupulous use of his own tooth brush and the almost astronomioal regularity of his visits for inspection to his dentist, can scaroely fail to be struck by the lamentable contrast between his own teeth and those of the happy-go-lucky Berberee servant whom be employs. Needlees to say, explanations of a fact so striking have uot been lacking : they have been, however, more abundant than adequate. The popular explanation is of great interest, because it introduces us at once to a biological oontro versy of which the popular explainer is perhaps csrcely cognisant It is Commonly said tvat our teeth are “degenerate."

Whereas the savage u es his, we have invented various moles of cooking and relrotion of food, not to mention the knife and fork, which render our teeth more or less superfluous. The con- seqoonce is that they haie fallen into comparative disuse.

Effects of this disuse are transmitted, from generation to generation of civilized people, and so the-phrase is justified that our teeth are degenerate. But the biclognt retorts that to accept this explanation is to make a quite unwarrantable assumption. He deuies in toto that the effects of disuse are transmissible by inheritance— Lamarck, Spenoer, and Darwin notwithstanding—and his argumeuts are so strong that we are1 compelled, or all but compelled, to believe him.

It so for as teeth are concerned, there can be no doubt that he is absolutely right. Ths Lamarckian explanation of the bad teeth of civilised man must be njeoted, even if it leaves us anchorless Better no theory than a bad one. The natural selectionist would say that what cannot bo explained on Lamarokian principles is readily capable of explanation by him. He would say teeth were of use in the struggle for existence and that they therefore tended to be selected whilst persons possessing bad teeth tended to die young and childless, It would be assumed in such an explanation that there are inborn and therefore transmissible tendencies to have good or bad teeth.Such an explanation does very well in a thousand cases, but it really counts for vey little in the present instance.

As in the case of the asserted degeneracy of the national physique, we are ltid to the much more bopefol proposition that the badness of our teeth does not depend upon inborn characters at all, but for each individual is a consequence of his individual circumstances daring his existence as an individual. In other words, the general rnle is, on this much more probable doctrine, that at birth we all have a pretty fair start in tha matter of teo'h. We do not it herit the defect of decay in our parents’ teeth, nor are our own teeth likely to be the worse because our parents have allowed the cook and the kuife to do part of tha work which a savage would have done with bis teeth. Is there, than, any particular direction to which we may tarn for the environmental factors which determine the lamentable state of the average civilized month I Before attempting to answertbis question it is well to realise the immediate cause of dental decay.

A tooth decays simply because aoids are produced in the month, which act chemically apon, and thereby dissolve the salts, mainly of time, which constitute the enamel covering of the tooth. Now, the characteristic secretions of the month are not acid, hot very definitely alkaline, as might well be expected The acids which destroy our teeth are not to be found, again, in the food; they are the products, with the rarest exceptions, of bacteria This is a comparatively recent and, of coarse, a capital disoovery. The conolniiion would appear to ba that wo most adopt a system of antiseptios. In this belief, the present writer’s teeth, like those ot every one cf his readers, were subjected, half an hoar sgo, on getting ap, to the action of an antiseptic and alkaline dentifrice. On this sodre, the advantage of the civilised man over the savage would appear to be great; and yet the savage alwsy beats ns. The valoe of the tooth brash and dentif ices has probably been immensely cver-.ated. Wo must probe farther still. The present brief note has been suggested by my reading of a little book jost published by Dr. Sim Wallace, whereip--tbe author adduces farther arguments in favour of his view that our teeth decay because of the manner in which our diet is deprived of its coarser parts, and is so prepared and oonsnmed that it tends to lodge in the month, affording an excellent diet for acidprodacing bacteria and thus leading to acid solution or the enanSel. I have left myself no space in which to disoass Dr. Wallace’s cogent contentions. At any rate, it is quite certain that civilised man, pins the tocth-brosb and antiseptics, makes a very poor show in comparison with the unaided dog or savage, and if Dr. Wallaoe is not right, it spoms to be at least certain that no one else is.

A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,
